I respectfully disagree with this statement. 
Riven, by nature, is a noobstomp-type champion, one that is difficult to take down without proper team coordination. Even though there is a lot of hate against Riven, she's not consistently picked or banned at the highest levels of play, unlike Zed. 

In my opinion, she is already balanced for the upper end, yet she still faces near-universal hatred at Silver and Bronze tiers due to her snowball ability and mobility; low-end players have issues fighting Riven due to a lack of skill kiting. If this change was completely implemented, I think that balancing Riven would be a bigger nightmare than it already is.

I see what your point is, I'd just like to respectfully disagree. Maybe you could elaborate further?

Sure, I'll try to explain my thoughts here. 

Current Riven is tough to balance because her damage is applied over such a variable time frame. Without animation canceling, she throws out her damage over, say, 6 seconds.* With animation canceling, she throws out the exact same damage over 2 seconds. This inconsistency raises the question of whether her damage should be balanced for the 6s state or the 2s state. Doing 1k damage over 6s is a much different thing than doing 1k damage over 2s.

Even assuming that Riven is currently balanced (for some part of the playerbase), you can't just leave her alone. Because balance is entirely relative, changes to other champs, items, or meta shifts affect Riven's balance. See Tristana's rise from obscurity and subsequent nerfs due to the IE/BT changes some time ago.

As such, it's not a matter of hatred by lower-MMR players, usage at high-MMR, or even current balance state. Automatic animation canceling would undoubtedly lessen her variation in damage. Rather than messing with "Oh, Riven does anywhere from 600 to 1.5k damage over 2s," dealing with "Okay, Riven does about 1k damage over 2s" is a much more straight-forward task.


*All numbers are completely arbitrary and should be treated as such.

I don't think Riot intended for you to be able to artificially increase your damage output through higher apm. I think Riven's q is currently unique in the fact that it is the only skill in the game where you can artificially increase your dps, through more apm, while not resulting in any clear gameplay decisions/counterplay offered to the enemy. Simply put, if the enemy Riven can animation cancel she will do a lot more damage in a smaller time frame than a Riven who cannot.

I see this making Riven less about how fast you can cancel your animations, and more about your game decisions which isn't necessarily a bad thing.

Now as to whether this will lower her skill cap, it may to a degree mechanically but when I look at other high skillcap champions Yasuo, Ahri, Lee Sin, Vayne they all have in common high mobility and outplay potential through dodging skill shots etc. In this sense I think that Riven will remain a high skillcap champion, 4 mobility skills on a very short cool down and how effectively those skills can be used will be what determines the skill of a Riven.

To give a bit of context for a discussion, I'd like to add something that Meddler wrote himself in a previous developer journal regarding [meaningful choices](http://na.leagueoflegends.com/en/news/game-updates/features/lol-design-values-depth-meaningful-choices):

> Meaningful choice adds a lot to a game, but it’s not an essential part of every element. Skillshots or challenging combos, for example, can be satisfying skill tests for many, even if the correct play is the same every time...
> In League, a lack of meaningful choice is worth accepting either because of the **benefits a single option brings to the rest of the game**, or because the **choice is meaningful to other players**.

I'm not arguing for the change either way, but I think it might be useful to frame any arguments in the current design values held by Riot. 

Is optimizing damage through animation canceling Riven's Q versus not animation canceling a meaningful choice? If so, how is the choice meaningful? Is there a different choice in regards to her Q that is perhaps better in other situations? (I hear that Riven Qs without animation canceling travels farther thus better for movement, but I don't know for sure. Just hearsay from a reddit post. I defer to Riven mains for the facts.)

If the choice isn't meaningful (i.e. it's always optimal to animation cancel Riven's Q), then is the mechanic worth accepting? What are the **benefits** for having animation canceling Riven's Q be the best possible choice in all cases? Is the choice to animation cancel Riven's Qs a choice that is **meaningful to other players**? To your opponents? To your allies?

Finally, I think it appropriate to add something about League of Legends evolution that Morello spoke about in the [original design values post](http://na.leagueoflegends.com/en/news/game-updates/features/dev-blog-design-values-league-legends):

> Players and designers are both a part of the League of Legends experience and evolution doesn't come through inaction. Our commitment to evolution means we can keep League healthy and dynamic over a number of years. Mistakes will be made along the way, but with player feedback and consistent iteration, we can create a constantly improving, ever-evolving game.

Due to the unintended side effects of certain changes to Riven's Q, I think some idiosyncrasies have been exposed in Riven's design, in player-design value expectations, and even perhaps in Riot's own internal brain trust. If you feel that some certain values are not being appreciated, then I would urge players to voice their opinion on why certain values have more consideration into the design of League of Legends. While I don't think Riot can automatically pivot to incorporate different core values immediately, I do think we can help to influence the evolution of the game with heartfelt, but succinct communication. Be passionate, but be clear. Don't devolve into hyperbole and bile spewing and maybe everyone can come out ahead.

Please keep this change. This is a simple matter of "clarity" as Riot has been choosing to call it recently.  The Animation cancelling that Riven can exploit the way she does is, correct me if I'm wrong, and unintended function. Therefore, people who know of and how to cancel the ability animations will automatically have an advantage over those who don't. Just like people who knew the timers of the jungle camps had an edge over the junglers that didn't. This is a case of fighting the system, and there is no other champion that can exploit something like this. (I'm not counting flashing ability windups since any champion can do that.)

My biggest problem with this is that this kinda of animation cancelling is its non intuitive and leads to a large disparity in the speed of execution. A standard Riven combo, with out animation canceling can take about 6-8 seconds, where as if you can cancel the animations that same combo only takes about 2-3. That's a whole 4 seconds, which as we all know is a very long time in League.

I think for "clarity's sake" that there are only two real options here, either A) Keep the change, or B) Lock Riven into her animations, and I don't think anyone wants the latter.

I would really like to hear your opinions on the matter.
